ygData.subject: Re: Online Video of Keynote Talk on "Searching Without Objectives"
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Sure, it s always good to be able to point out objectives that are going to be very hard for us.  The trick of course is that we don t know yet how hard

Hi Jeff, I appreciate the feedback.  I respond to your comments below:

-=
-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jeffclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ken-
>=
 
> I watched this keynote and greatly enjoyed it. Thanks for posting it.
>=
 
> I had a few thoughts that I think could improve future versions of your=

> argument. I know you are interested in constantly optimizing these pitch=
es,
> so here are my thoughts, whatever they are worth.
> 1. synthetic sola=
r panels are much more efficient than photosynthesis. so it
> seems odd to =
use that as an example of something nature dominates us on.
> there are so =
many examples where we don't compare at all to natural designs,
> that you =
might raise fewer red flags by going with an undebatable one.
> 2. we know =
a lot about cancer and I think we will solve it soon (~20-40
> years). I wo=
uld say that is more like the moon mission. we could solve it in
> less tha=
n 20 years if we dedicated an inordinate amount of resources to it.
> I thi=
nk you do better to pick things like levitation, time-travel, or
> somethin=
g in between, because in that case I cannot bring to mind the steps
> that =
need to be taken to get there, which is exactly your point. with
> cancer, =
many researchers will tell you that we do know a ton of things that
> need =
to be done, and it is just a matter of doing them (and building the
> techn=
ology to allow them to scale).
> 3. the mission to the moon wasn't one step=
ping stone away, but many. your
> argument works, but should be "a handful =
of stepping stones away" vs. a
> dozens/hundreds of stepping stones away"
>=
 
> All of those are very minor points, however. Overall I like the pitch.
=
> 

Sure, it's always good to be able to point out objectives that are goin=
g to be very hard for us.  The trick of course is that we don't know yet ho=
w hard something is that we have not yet achieved.  Yet one thing to keep i=
n mind about some of these examples (e.g. photosynthesis) is that I'm only =
pointing out that nature inspires us with its achievements and that they we=
re not its objectives.  So whether or not we've really beat it or not I don=
't think is the instrumental issue behind my point. For example, even if we=
 achieve AI in the future, the point that intelligence was an amazing (and =
non-objective) discovery of natural evolution still stands.  

Some of your=
 specific points are interesting - as I mentioned to you in private, I've b=
een getting some conflicting information on whether or not photosynthesis w=
orks better than synthetic methods, but what Colin said about it makes some=
 sense.  As for cancer, I'm not a big fan of futurologist types of predicti=
ons that "amazing objective X will be achieved in 20-40 years."  We've hear=
d that before from the "experts" in AI too.  Often the experts are blind to=
 deception in their very own search space (which is why it's deceptive), so=
 you can't really trust an expert to tell you what's around the corner in t=
he future.  But the key for me is that if we do cure cancer soon, then it's=
 only one stepping stone away anyway, so there's no real inconsistency ther=
e.

The specific number of stepping stones is obviously subjective.  That i=
s, "one stepping stone away" is meant as a qualitative description.  of cou=
rse you can't really quantify precisely how many there are.  So if you pref=
er "a few" to "one," we still pretty much mean the same thing.  The point i=
s when something is "many" away, we aren't going to get there as an objecti=
ve.

Unfortunately, right at the moment in the video where I mention the sp=
ace program there was about 1 minute of video lost.  If you watch carefully=
 you can see the cut/glitch.  That was because they had to change tapes at =
that moment (so they tell me), so unfortunately you didn't actually see my =
argument regarding the space program.  

But I think it's a little confusin=
g to talk about any of these examples at a single snapshot in time (e.g. no=
w).  Of course, there will always be a moment when we are just a stepping s=
tone away from anything, and of course for anything we actually have alread=
y accomplished, we literally were once a stepping stone away.  But the larg=
er point is that many stepping stones always preceded that moment, and when=
 we were back at those far-prior stepping stones, the necessary stepping st=
ones that lay ahead would be impossible to predict.  Hence the futility of =
the objective.

> Here is a question I got when telling someone about your =
speech. They
> pointed out that directed evolution works all the time in an=
imal breeding
> (think chihuahuas and great danes vs. their ancestors). Exp=
erimental
> biologists also often find that animals can be bred in all sort=
s of
> directions. A prof at MSU who does that recently told a room of peop=
le that
> "we can basically get the animals to vary on any dimension we foc=
us on."
> That seems to contradict the argument that goal-oriented selectio=
n will
> never work. 
> 
> I can think of rebuttals to this argument (I in =
fact gave them to the person
> who raised the issue), but I would be intere=
sted to hear your take.
> 

I think it's a great example of how we've built=
 up this mythology in our society that we can guide our endeavors through o=
bjectives.  These scientists notice that they can vary animals along certai=
n selected dimensions and then effectively delude themselves into thinking =
by implication that such a capability means that can jump more than a stepp=
ing-stone away.  If only that were true.

If it were true, then there are a=
 couple "dimensions" I am sure our super-breeder colleagues would have trav=
ersed by now:

-First, clearly, they would have bred dogs to be able to tal=
k.  I don't know why they wasted so much time breeding stuff like fluffines=
s or fetching when the truth is everyone would like dogs to be able to tell=
 us what they're thinking.

-Second, without a doubt, they would have bred =
horses to have wings.  I don't see why this "dimension" is not fair game.  =
After all, it can start from just a little bulge at the hips and a little a=
erodynamic optimization, and soon enough we'd have flying horses, which wou=
ld be way more convenient for many things than riding horses that are stuck=
 pathetically to the ground.

So I think what such scientists are saying is=
 a bit sensationalistic, and not really serious.  But to give them the bene=
fit of the doubt I'm guessing that part of it just a way to raise excitemen=
t rather than a literal claim.

The reality is, picking an animal to breed =
is a great example of how stranded we are on the stepping stones we happen =
to have now.  Dogs breeders can only take us so far away from dogs, as can =
horse breeders from horses.  In the end, our vision of how to move beyond o=
ne stepping stone away is clouded by the vast complexity of the search spac=
e.  The best we can do is pick the most promising stepping stone from among=
 those nature has provided us, which, in fact, is exactly why non-objective=
 process are so powerful.  They are based on choosing promising stepping st=
ones, which means evaluating the potential of where you are as opposed to t=
he promise of getting where you want to be.


> PS. I can't believe you wer=
e so nice to the creationist. I would have said
> something like "People wh=
o deny the overwhelming and obvious evidence for
> evolution have not revie=
wed the evidence with a rational, open mind. They
> have simply come to the=
 wrong conclusion, because they are intentionally
> misleading themselves o=
r because whoever controls their access to
> information is misleading them=
."  That sounds less nice, but I don't think
> we should be so nice to peop=
le who are so willfully ignorant, or the
> converts of those who are.
> 

M=
y thinking behind how I handled the creationist question is that he was abo=
ut to completely derail the focus of the audience away from my point and in=
to the creationist-evolutionist debate.  That debate is so charged and emot=
ional that injecting it into anything is a formula for distraction.  I don'=
t want everyone in the audience to walk away from my talk engaged in a heat=
ed discussion of the insanity of creationism; I want them thinking about my=
 talk.  So what I did was basically confuse him - if you notice, he wasn't =
sure how to respond to my response, which I think is a great thing.  It kep=
t the topic on objectives instead of how crazy one side or the other is.  I=
f I had told him that he is "misleading himself" it would have led to a won=
derful theatrical exchange, but ruined the focus on my overall point.

> 
>=
 PPS. You made any progress on thinking up an algorithmic way to quantify
>=
 interestingess?
> 
> 

Of course that is a very deep topic, and we are loo=
king at it.  I think we have some new ideas in the pipeline that give some =
insight into it, but truly formalizing what interestingness means is probab=
ly not going to happen anytime soon.  I think it's more than one stepping s=
tone away :)  Of course, interestingness and novelty are highly related to =
each other, though not exactly the same.

ken
